Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit with a time-varying admittance matrix \\( Y(t) \\), and a network described by the voltage-current relationship \\( I = Y(t)V \\). We examine the impact of a transformation represented by the matrix function \\( P(t) = e^{Qt} \\), where Q is a constant matrix, that affects the voltage vector over time.

If the transformation \\( P(t) \\) is applied to the voltage vector \\( V_0 \\) at t = 0, and then the system evolves to time T under the rule \\( I = Y(t)V \\) without further intervention, will the current vector \\( I(T) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( V_0 \\) was evolved directly under the rule without transformation?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( P(t) \\) to the voltage vector alters its initial state significantly, changing the resulting effective voltage applied to the circuit. As Y(t) multiplies a different initial \( V(T) \), calculated from \\( P(T)V_0 \\), the resulting current \\( I(T) \\) will differ unless Q and Y(t) exhibit specific commutative properties.
